title: Phu Juck
author: Phu Juck
content: Hello everyone! I'm not a coder personally, but in my opinion, doing a research on Bitcoin's fundamentals is very important for everyone because of many aspects: - understanding how Bitcoin works and what makes it better compared to Altcoins- preventing costly mistakes resulting from a lack of knowledge about BitcoinI'm currently searching for interesting blog posts about Bitcoin's fundamentals written by coders but written in an understandable way for average people (who are not coders). So far, in my list is for example: - MURCH and his website: https://murch.one/ (but he's not very active)- JAMESON LOPP and his website: https://www.lopp.net/bitcoin-information.html (he's very atice but it's very technical sometimes for coders)I also know about Bitcoin Stack Exchange and Bitcointalk of course, but I don't know if it's always a good source because everyone can reply (I don't know if some people are not educated enough). I'm looking forward to your contributions. I just want to look for Bitcoin's fundamentals for now, what is important for average people to know.

comments.author: Pmalek
comments.body: You can give Mastering Bitcoin by Andreas Antonopoulos a try if you want to. One version is available on GitHub.https://github.com/bitcoinbook/bitcoinbook/blob/develop/book.asciidocAndreas also created a Bitcoin for Beginners playlist on YouTube.https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLPQwGV1aLnTuN6kdNWlElfr2tzigB9NnjOur forum mate fillippone created a solid collection of blogs and videos.5 Resources to teach Average Joe about Bitcoin There is also learn me a bitcoin by By Greg Walker.https://learnmeabitcoin.com/

comments.author: jamyr
comments.body: Blog posts are interesting, but I utilized chat gpt and gave a few guidelines to give a response which went like this:Quote from: chatgpt chat.openai.comResearching about the fundamentals of Bitcoin is a crucial step in understanding the world of cryptocurrency. It is essential to use reliable sources of information to ensure that the information gathered is accurate and trustworthy. This essay will provide a guide on how to list sources properly when researching about Bitcoin fundamentals.Academic Journals: Academic journals are a reliable source of information when it comes to researching Bitcoin fundamentals. Some of the top journals in the field include the Journal of Financial Economics, Journal of Monetary Economics, and the Journal of Economic Perspectives.Example citation: Nakamoto, S. (2008). Bitcoin: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System. Retrieved from https://bitcoin.org/bitcoin.pdfResearch Papers: Research papers are a great source of information on Bitcoin fundamentals, as they provide a detailed analysis of specific topics. Some of the top research papers include "An Empirical Analysis of Bitcoin Transaction Fees" by Holden, Krause, and Pousttchi and "Bitcoin: An Innovative Alternative Digital Currency" by Al-Qudah and Al-Zoubi.Example citation: Holden, S. E., Krause, M. G., & Pousttchi, K. (2018). An Empirical Analysis of Bitcoin Transaction Fees. Journal of Business Research, 89, 55-64. doi: 10.1016/j.jbusres.2018.02.019Books: Books are a great source of information when it comes to understanding the basics of Bitcoin. Some of the top books in the field include "The Bitcoin Standard: The Decentralized Alternative to Central Banking" by Saifedean Ammous and "Mastering Bitcoin: Unlocking Digital Cryptocurrencies" by Andreas Antonopoulos.Example citation: Ammous, S. (2018). The Bitcoin Standard: The Decentralized Alternative to Central Banking. Hoboken, NJ: Wiley.Websites: Websites are a great source of information on Bitcoin fundamentals, especially for up-to-date news and market analysis. Some of the top websites include Bitcoin.org, Coindesk.com, and Bitcoin Magazine.Example citation: "What is Bitcoin?" (2021). Bitcoin.org. Retrieved from https://bitcoin.org/en/faqWhite Papers: White papers are official documents that provide detailed information on the technical aspects of Bitcoin. The most notable white paper is the original Bitcoin white paper written by Satoshi Nakamoto.Example citation: Nakamoto, S. (2008). Bitcoin: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System. Retrieved from https://bitcoin.org/bitcoin.pdfIn conclusion, using reliable sources is essential when researching about Bitcoin fundamentals. Properly citing sources is important to ensure that the information gathered is accurate and trustworthy. When listing sources, it is important to include the author, title, publication date, and the website or journal where the information was found. By following these guidelines, researchers can ensure that their work is credible and informative.I also asked it to refer on bitcointalk posts and it gave me:Quote from: chatgpt chat.openai.comWhen researching about Bitcoin fundamentals within the Bitcointalk.org forum, it is essential to ensure that the sources used are reliable and trustworthy. Here are some tips on how to list sources properly when researching within the Bitcointalk.org forum:Forum Threads: Forum threads are an excellent source of information on Bitcoin fundamentals. However, it is crucial to ensure that the information is accurate and comes from a reputable source. When referencing forum threads, include the thread title, author, and date of the post.Example citation: Satoshi Nakamoto. (2009, November 9). Bitcoin P2P e-cash paper [Forum thread]. Retrieved from https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=3878.msg52748#msg52748User Profiles: User profiles on the Bitcointalk.org forum can provide valuable information on the user's expertise and experience in the Bitcoin space. When referencing user profiles, include the username, the date of the post, and the URL of the user's profile.Example citation: JohnDoe. (2022, February 1). Re: Bitcoin Mining [Forum post]. Retrieved from https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?action=profile;u=12345External Links: External links posted within the Bitcointalk.org forum can provide additional information on Bitcoin fundamentals. However, it is important to ensure that the external source is reputable and reliable. When referencing external links, include the title of the article or website, the author, the date of publication, and the URL.Example citation: Smith, J. (2022, March 1). The Future of Bitcoin [Web article]. Retrieved from https://www.example.com/the-future-of-bitcoinBitcointalk.org Rules: The rules and guidelines posted on the Bitcointalk.org forum can provide valuable information on how to conduct research within the forum. When referencing the Bitcointalk.org rules, include the title of the rule or guideline and the date of publication.Example citation: Bitcointalk.org. (2022). Rules and Guidelines [Forum thread]. Retrieved from https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=703657.0In conclusion, the Bitcointalk.org forum can provide valuable information on Bitcoin fundamentals. When listing sources from the forum, it is important to ensure that the information is accurate and comes from reputable sources. Properly citing sources within the forum can help to ensure that the information gathered is credible and informative.Hope these helps.

comments.author: sha420hashcollision
comments.body: Read the white paper:https://bitcoin.org/bitcoin.pdfLearn about why self custody is vital:https://www.investopedia.com/what-went-wrong-with-ftx-6828447https://www.investopedia.com/terms/m/mt-gox.asphttps://medium.com/stablecorp/what-happens-after-the-hack-a-deep-dive-into-defi-exploits-and-recoveries-4aa42c3fc0b5https://www.ledger.com/academy/not-your-keys-not-your-coins-why-it-mattersTHIS IS WHERE IT GETS EXTREMELY TECHNICALLearn about secure private key generation:https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0032.mediawikihttps://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0044.mediawikiLearn about p2pkh (legacy standard) bitcoin addresses:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1n4g3eYX1UILearn about segwit:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NOYNZB5BCHM (sorry to your left ear lol)https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n-jAUaSkcAA (this gets into taproot)Learn about taproot:https://github.com/bitcoinops/taproot-workshopI am still going through taproot workshop myself.Unfortunately I don't think simple explanations will cut it, there is no simple way to explain what is going on and be honest about it at the same time in my opinion. Bitcoin is complex and extremely important.To be extra honest I think what you are asking for is inherently an oxymoron, fundamentals that are simple are simple to break. Most of the Bitcoin network's security is based on Elliptic Curve Discrete Log Hardness, the only way you can simplify that is saying "really hard math" but that obviously says nothing about what is really happening.
